biogHist.abstract: Werribee Farm School, near Wundowie, was established by the Methodist Church in 1928 to train boys aged 10 to14 years in farm work. By 1953, girls were admitted to Werribee (then called 'Allandale') with their brothers. The property was sold in 1962.
biogHist.p: Werribee Farm School, near Wundowie, was established by the Methodist Church in November 1928 to train boys aged 10 to14 years in farm work.

In 1938, the objectives of the Werribee Boys' Home (Farm School) were described in the Report by the Royal Commissioner on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System (p.lxix) as 'housing and training boys in farm pursuits' and accommodating 'boys who, on prospects, appear to have less opportunity than the average boy (e.g., boys from poor homes) and destitute orphan boys.'

The Royal Commissioner recommended (p.lxx) that the Government pay a maintenance allowance of 10 shillings per week for each 'destitute orphan boy' at Werribee provided the school undertook vocational and general education and training to the satisfaction of the Education Department. By 1940, this recommendation had not been implemented.
By 1953, girls were admitted to Werribee (by then called 'Allandale') with their brothers. The property was sold in 1962.

archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

'Farm Schools' is an excerpt from the Report of the Royal Commission on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System which is held online by the Parliament of Western Australia. It gives an overview of the four Farm Schools operating in WA in 1938: Fairbridge Farm School; Tardun Agricultural College; Werribee Boys' Home; and the Unemployed Boys' Farm at Wokalup. The full Report is very large and difficult to download, so this relevant excerpt has been reproduced for quick downloading from the Find & Connect web resource.

archref.abstract: The 'Homes' Herald was a newsletter of the Methodist Homes for Children. This is a copy of the December 1966 edition. It has a picture of the new hostel ('Cooinda') in Mt Lawley and a photo of some young women who lived there. There are also photos of buildings at the Mofflyn site in Victoria Park and a photo of children with 'Father Christmas'. There is news about donations and activities in the other Homes. The newsletter also tells readers how they can help.

archref.repository: Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia) Archives
archref.abstract: The 'Homes' Herald was a newsletter of the Methodist Homes for Children. The December 1965 edition is held in the Children's Homes File at the Uniting Church Archive in Perth. This edition has a photo of some kindergarten children acting in their Christmas play. There are also photos of buildings and children at the Mofflyn site in Victoria Park and information about the Homes and children's activities.

This song was published in The Barefoot Boys of Werribee on page 105. It comes from a chapter by Harry Lucas. Harry has made a comment about the song, which is included in the picture here. The song was written by one of the Superintendents of Werribee, Mr Cyril Palmer. Mr Palmer was Superintendent from 1937 to 1945.

This is a picture of the front cover of the book The Barefoot Boys of Werribee which was run by the Methodist Homes for Children from 1929 to 1962. The authors believe that the photo on the front cover of the book comes from an album made by the daughter of Mrs GE Jones, who was Matron at Werribee from 1933 to 1935.
